captions.text:
How to Pick a Great Airline Seat. Don't get
stuck in a middle seat near a bathroom on

your next flight. With a little time and effort,
you can be sitting pretty. You will need Priorities

A website with airplane seating diagrams An
early booking and a seat upgrade membership.

Step 1. There is no single "best seat" on
an airplane — all have their pros and cons

— so decide what's important to you. Legroom?
Peace and quiet? A quick exit? A smooth ride?

Step 2. Don't assume anything about a seat
without checking it out. Some bulkhead seats

_don't_ offer extra legroom, some "window"
seats are _between_ windows and therefore

offer little view, and many exit seats, while
providing more legroom, are narrower than

other seats. Find out what kind of plane you'll
be on and then visit "seatexpert.com":http://

or "seatguru.com":http://. Click on any seat
to see its pros and cons. Step 3. Pay a small

fee to ensure you get a seat with the most
legroom. Many airlines now identify their

best seats on their websites and charge for
them accordingly. Step 4. Take reclining into

account. If you like to sit back, avoid the
last rows in any section. If you hate people

leaning into your lap, try to snare an exit
seat; the seats in front of those rows usually

don't recline. Exit row seats are often not
assigned until check-in. To snag one, get

to the airport early. Step 5. Consider the
pitch of the seat, which is the distance between

your seat and the one in front of you. You'll
find this information on airline seat websites.

Step 6. Take turbulence into account. If you're
a white-knuckle flyer, sit over the front

of the wing; that's where you're least likely
to feel turbulence. Avoid the back, where

you'll feel every bump. Step 7. If you need
peace and quiet, avoid sitting in the back,

where the engines are the loudest. And steer
clear of the bulkhead, where families with

babies are usually seated. Step 8. When you
buy your ticket, be sure to book your specific

seat, either online or by calling the airline
directly. Increase your odds of sitting beside

an empty middle seat by requesting a back
row where either the aisle or window seat

is already booked. The middle seats in back
rows fill up last. Step 9. Check back 24 hours

before your flight; this is when prime seating
often is released. Plus, airlines occasionally

switch planes, possibly turning your chosen
seat into an undesirable one! Step 10. If

you're a frequent flyer, consider joining
an airline program that guarantees a good

seat for an annual fee. Did you know The average
airline seat in coach is just 17.2 inches
wide.

title: How to Pick a Great Airline Seat

comments.text: i personally think that the exit seats are best, i also like first class﻿

comments.author: rodri barahona

comments.text:
Either the front seats, or the ones above the wing. Those are quieter, with 
more legroom and you get serviced faster. If you are at the back, you have 
to wait until everyone gets serviced, before you get drinks and food.
Seats in front of the engine are only loud during take off. Then they quiet 
down, cause the engines aren't running at full power.
Also pray that the airline has cocked up your economy seat and given you a 
1st class one XD
Had this happen 2 times. Most comfortable plane trip ever XD﻿
comments.author: megadriver6

comments.text: I chose a quick exit seat in case the plane crashes﻿
comments.author: Mai Fahy

comments.text:
2 things incorrect about this video. 

1. The engines usually aren't the loudest in the aft unless the engines are 
in the back. If you are in First Class on a one deck aircraft however, you 
are bound to hear the engine. This is because a lot of the noise is heard 
in front of the fan.

2. You can sit anywhere on the wing for it to be comfortable, even just 1 
seat behind it. This if because the framing that holds the wings to the 
aircraft is structured there.﻿
comments.author: David Roscilo

comments.text:

comments.text:
This video was useless. OF COURSE if you pay more you can get a premium 
seat. I fly often. Airlines have been cutting down on routes - there is 
almost no empty seats left on most flights anymore. I used to be able to 
request an exit row seat or bulkhead by checking in very early, but now 
most airlines charge for these seats now! Unless you fly first class, your 
f*cked.
